column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: CBA's investor relations program facilitates two-way communication between the Bank and its shareholders. Shareholders can also send CBA communications directly or via CBA's share registry, Link Market Services. Shareholders can contact CBA Investor Relations directly through multiple channels, including a dedicated telephone line, by email and post.
column20: Investor relations program, communication, share registry

column6: Approach to stakeholder engagement
column13: CBA's dedicated Customer and Community Advocacy team represents the voice of the customer and community at the Bank, helping CBA find and fix negative impacts and improve its products and services. CBA engages with them through its Community Council and regular community visits.
column20: Customer and Community Advocacy team, Community Council, community visit

column6: Collective bargaining agreements
column7: As of June 2023, approximately 85% of employees are covered by the Commonwealth Bank Group EA (covers Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Commonwealth Securities, Colonial Services, Commonwealth Insurance) or the Bankwest EA.

column6: Process to determine material topics
column13: CBA's materiality assessment enables it to engage with stakeholders and identify topics with the potential to most impact the Australian people, community and environment. It also helps CBA better understand the Bank's ability to influence these impacts Ã¢ÂÂ directly or indirectly. The process draws on external frameworks and resources, such as the Global Reporting Initiative, the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board, and the International Integrated Reporting Framework.

column6: List of material topics
column7: CBA's material topics are customer experience and support, talent attraction and retention, risk management, and cyber security.

column6: Management of material topics
column13: CBA's Group Customer Advocate reviewed coercive relationship debt, a highly sensitive form of financial abuse, which often goes unrecognised by customers until acute impacts are felt. The review produced several recommendations that are being implemented throughout the Bank. These include tailored hardship support, employee and customer education, and CBA process updates.
column20: Group Customer Advocate, coercive relationship debt, financial abuse

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column7: CBA generated $43,182 million in revenues in 2023.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: This year, CBA launched the Building Resilience Pilot program with the support of Edge Impact. The program aims to provide customers with information and tools to make informed decisions regarding their home's climate resilience and to identify areas of their homes that may increase their vulnerability to potential climate hazards.
column20: Building Resilience Pilot, Edge Impact, climate resilience

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA's Behavioural Science Centre of Excellence is working to understand customer climate-action drivers and intentions. CBA will use these findings to understand how CBA can encourage more customers to take action on climate change and educate them on how CBA can support them in achieving their personal climate goals
column20: Behavioural Science Centre of Excellence, climate-action driver, climate goal

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA used scenario modelling to explore a pathway to achieving its 2030 target. CBA drew on AEMO and the IEA insights to chart an indicative scenario, highlighting dependency on grid decarbonisation and actions homeowners can take to reduce emissions.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA's Green Home Offer incentivises customers to make their homes more energy efficient to a Nationwide House Energy Rating Scheme (NatHERS) 7-star rating or higher. It encourages them to take tangible steps to reduce their carbon footprint. When customers build, buy or renovate their homes in this way, they become eligible for a lower standard variable rate.
column20: Green Home Offer, NatHERS, carbon footprint

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA's Property Sustainability Upgrade Loan provides low-free financing options for its customers with existing buildings to upgrade their properties' energy and water efficiency, reduce carbon emissions, and achieve higher NABERS ratings on their buildings.
column20: Property Sustainability Upgrade Loan, low-free financing, NABERS

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA supported Collective Capital in purchasing a commercial property in Melbourne and provided a Property Sustainability Upgrade Loan to help them upgrade the building. Through CBA's financing support, Collective Capital is investing in improvements to the building's heating, ventilation and air conditioning, elevators, water units and lighting.
column20: Collective Capital, commercial property, Property Sustainability Upgrade

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA uses climate scenario analysis to understand its exposure to strategic, financial and non-financial risks arising from climate change and how they may impact its decision-making. This year, CBA refined and developed new insights and updated its view of scenarios.
column20: Climate scenario analysis, climate change, insight, decision-making

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: This year, CBA used ENCORE to deepen its understanding of potential nature-related impacts and dependencies in its business and corporate lending portfolio. The analysis demonstrated that agriculture highly depends on nature for its continued productivity. Mining had the highest overall impact, followed by electricity and utilities, manufacturing, transportation, and construction. Agriculture, forestry, fishing, and mining are the highest impact and dependency sectors.
column20: ENCORE, nature-related impact, corporate lending portfolio

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: CBA supported North Queensland Airport with a Sustainability-Linked Loan that included targets on emissions, biodiversity and a partnership with First Nations peoples. The loan incentivises North Queensland Airport to improve the habitat around them for three threatened species. The Dawul Wuru Aboriginal Corporation's Yirrganydji Land and Sea Ranger program will support North Queensland Airport in delivering against the loan's biodiversity target by incorporating the skills and knowledge of First Nations peoples.

column7: CBA received no financial assistance from the government in the 2023 financial year.

Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column13: CBA is committed to fostering a culture where its people and others feel safe to speak up on matters or conduct that concerns them. The Group Whistleblower Policy clarifies how the Group will support and protect those who express their concerns and how concerns can be raised and managed.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: CBA's Code of Conduct sets expectations for how it acts, solves problems and makes decisions. It is regularly reviewed to ensure it remains current with CBA's business needs and is aligned with customer and community expectations. This year, the Code was updated to clarify and reinforce CBA's responsibilities concerning the responsible use of customer information and data.
column20: Code of Conduct, community expectation, decision

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column13: The Group is committed to embedding a zero-risk appetite culture for bribery, corruption and facilitation payments. An Anti-Bribery and Corruption (AB&C) framework, comprising a Group AB&C Policy and Standard, has been created to formally acknowledge and promote awareness and understanding of the serious nature of bribery and corruption.
column20: Anti-Bribery & Corruption Framework, zero-risk appetite, awareness

column6: Legal actions for anti-competitive behavior, anti-trust, and monopoly practices
column13: CBA's Strategic Risk Management Framework considers the impact of the Group's strategy of dynamically evolving material current and emerging risks arising from changes in the competitive landscape, emerging technologies, macroeconomic conditions, the regulatory and political environment, and social expectations.
column20: Strategic Risk Management Framework, emerging risk, competitive landscape
